questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening pain in his left heel over the past 3 months. He says that the pain is worse in the morning when he gets up from the bed but decreases as he starts walking. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with prediabetes. He started jogging daily and working out in an attempt to lose weight. He does not take any medications. He drinks 3–4 beers on weekends but does not smoke or use illicit drugs. He is 188 cm (6 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 109 kg (240 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tenderness over the medial aspect of the left heel's inferior surface and worsening of the pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes. The pain is not reproduced upon squeezing the sides of the heel. An x-ray of the foot shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Recurrent microtrauma to the Achilles tendon
Impingement of the S1 nerve root

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Recurrent microtrauma to the Achilles tendon leads to Achilles tendinopathy, which manifests with heel pain. This condition commonly affects runners and individuals who, like this patient, suddenly increase the intensity of their training. However, patients with Achilles tendinopathy present with pain in the posterior heel (proximal to the insertion of the Achilles tendon) rather than with pain on the inferior surface of the heel.

B) INCORRECT:

Impingement of the S1 nerve root can cause pain in the S1 dermatome, which includes the heel. However, pain in this condition typically radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg into the sole. Furthermore, characteristic findings of S1 radiculopathy include a weakened plantar flexion, a decreased ankle reflex, a positive straight leg raise test, and sensation deficits in the S1 dermatome, none of which is seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with progressive heel pain suggestive of plantar fasciitis, a condition thought to be caused by degeneration of the plantar aponeurosis. Heel pain in plantar fasciitis is typically located on the inferior heel over the medial calcaneal tuberosity (the site of insertion of the plantar aponeurosis) and can be elicited by stretching the aponeurosis through passive dorsiflexion of the toes and simultaneous palpation along the plantar fascia. The pain is usually worse in the morning, gradually lessens with activity, and increases again towards the end of the day after long periods of weight-bearing. Obesity and overtraining (e.g., running) are risk factors associated with this condition. An x-ray of the foot is often normal; however, in some patients, a concurrent calcaneal heel spur is visible. Imaging is not necessary to establish the diagnosis but can help rule out differentials (e.g., fractures).

The initial treatment is conservative and includes rest, ice massage, a 2–3 week trial with NSAIDs, avoidance of flat shoes and barefoot walking, and stretching and strengthening exercises. Patients who do not improve under conservative therapy can be treated with locally injected glucocorticoids.
Image Description:

X-ray (lateral view)

A bony outgrowth (green overlay) projects from the calcaneal tuberosity at the origin of the plantar fascia.

C: calcaneus

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the retrocalcaneal bursa is seen in retrocalcaneal bursitis, which manifests with heel pain. This condition can affect runners and individuals who, like this patient, suddenly increase the intensity of their training or overtrain. However, patients with retrocalcaneal bursitis present with pain in the posterior heel and ankle rather than on the inferior surface of the heel.

E) INCORRECT:

Impingement of the tibial nerve causes tarsal tunnel syndrome (TTS), which can manifest with heel pain. TTS is most often part of the sequelae of traumatic ankle injuries but may also be the result of repetitive stress and improper running techniques (overpronation). However, unlike this patient's findings, pain in TTS usually worsens with activity and is typically accompanied by paresthesias. Focal tenderness on palpation would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

A stress fracture of the calcaneus manifests with heel pain that commonly begins in the morning upon weight bearing. This condition can be seen in individuals who are involved in activities that cause repetitive microtrauma in the foot, similar to this patient's intensive, daily running program. Because stress fractures are not always visible on radiography, an x-ray of the foot may be normal. This patient's pain decreases with physical activity whereas the pain in calcaneus stress fractures persists or increases with walking. There would also be tenderness over the medial and lateral aspects of the posterior heels, rather than the inferior surface. Finally, pain from a calcaneus stress fracture is characteristically elicited by squeezing the sides of the heel.
questions.hint: This condition is the most common cause of heel pain.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of pain and swelling in his left leg. He has a history of pancreatic cancer and is currently receiving chemotherapy. Three weeks ago, he had a similar episode in his right arm that resolved without treatment. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Palpation of the left leg shows a tender, cord-shaped structure medial to the medial condyle of the femur. The overlying skin is erythematous. Which of the following vessels is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The posterior tibial artery resides in the deep posterior compartment of the leg. Occlusion of this artery can be asymptomatic owing to collateral circulation to the foot or show areas of watershed ischemia marked by pale, cool tissue. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins.

B) INCORRECT:

The posterior tibial vein is a deep vein that courses through the deep posterior compartment of the leg. This vein is susceptible to clotting but classically presents with calf pain, especially on ankle dorsiflexion (Homan's sign). It would not be appreciated medial to the medial femoral condyles. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins.

C) INCORRECT:

The popliteal artery is the continuation of the superficial femoral artery as it courses through the popliteal fossa. A clot in this vessel would lead to acute arterial insufficiency in the tissues distal to the knee manifesting as pain, pallor, poikilothermia, pulselessness, paresthesias, and paralysis. The patient described here has pain alone, making limb ischemia exceptionally unlikely. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins.

D) INCORRECT:

The anterior tibial artery runs through the anterior compartment of the leg and is one of two major arterial inflows to the foot. Occlusion of this artery can be asymptomatic owing to collateral circulation to the foot or show areas of watershed ischemia marked by pale, cool tissue. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins.

E) INCORRECT:

The popliteal vein gives rise to the femoral vein as it passes through the popliteal fossa. This vessel is commonly affected in migratory thrombophlebitis and would present as a palpable cord. However, it is appreciated in the popliteal fossa between the tendons of the hamstring muscles.

F) INCORRECT:

The superficial femoral artery is the principal arterial supply to the leg. A clot in this vessel would lead to signs of acute arterial insufficiency: pain, pallor, poikilothermia, pulselessness, paresthesias, and paralysis. The patient described here has pain alone, making limb ischemia exceptionally unlikely. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins.

G) INCORRECT:

The external iliac artery courses through the deep pelvis. A clot in that vessel would lead to limb ischemia of the entire ipsilateral leg manifesting as pain, pallor, poikilothermia, pulselessness, paresthesias, and paralysis. The patient described here has pain alone, making limb ischemia exceptionally unlikely. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins.

H) CORRECT:

The great saphenous vein (GSV) originates at the base of the hallux, continues proximally by passing anterior to the medial malleolus, and then courses along the posterior aspect of the medial femoral condyle before running deep into the thigh to join the femoral vein. The GSV and the small saphenous vein make up the main veins of superficial venous system of the leg, which is commonly involved in cases of malignant migratory thrombophlebitis. Migratory thrombophlebitis in pancreatic cancer is believed to be a direct result of procoagulants by the tumor itself. This patient will require acute treatment with intravenous heparin followed by outpatient anticoagulation.
Image Description:

The superficial veins are depicted in the right leg:
- Great saphenous vein: arises from the medial end of the dorsal venous arch, courses in front of the medial malleolus, up the medial aspect of the leg, behind the medial border of the patella, and up the medial aspect of the thigh. It terminates by draining into the femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction, which is typically located ~4 cm inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.
- Short saphenous vein: arises from the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch, courses behind the lateral malleolus, and up the posterior aspect of the leg. It terminates by draining into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction, which usually lies in the popliteal fossa (not shown here).

The deep veins are depicted in the left leg:
- Peripheral deep veins: anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and fibular (peroneal) veins
- Popliteal vein: formed by the confluence of the peripheral deep veins
- Femoral vein: continuation of the popliteal vein. It begins at the adductor hiatus and accompanies the femoral artery throughout its course. The deep femoral vein (profunda femoris) is the main tributary of the femoral vein.
- External iliac vein: continuation of the femoral vein. It begins behind the inguinal ligament and drains into the common iliac vein.

I) INCORRECT:

The external iliac vein is a deep vein of the pelvis and proximal thigh. Clots in this vessel are exceptionally dangerous as they can easily migrate into the inferior vena cava and the pulmonary vasculature. However, this vein cannot be palpated on clinical exam and requires imaging to evaluate for clots. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins.

Acute, massive clot in the iliac venous system can lead to phlegmasia cerulea dolens.

J) INCORRECT:

The deep femoral vein travels alongside the deep femoral artery deep in the thigh. This vein is a common location for deep venous thrombosis and thrombophlebitis alike, but it would not be palpated medial to the medial condyle of the femur. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins.

K) INCORRECT:

The anterior tibial vein is a deep vein that runs parallel to the anterior tibial artery in the anterior compartment of the leg. In cases of thrombophlebitis, skin changes and pain are present along the anterior aspect of the leg but the vein can be difficult to palpate due to the overlying muscle bellies and the curved surface of the underlying tibia. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins.
questions.hint: Recurrent episodes of pain, swelling, and erythema in various locations in a patient with a history of pancreatic cancer are suggestive of malignant migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painful paresthesia in her right foot. Examination shows decreased sensation in the first interdigital space and a hallux valgus deformity. This patient's paresthesia is most likely caused by compression of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The superficial peroneal nerve provides sensory innervation to the anterior and lateral leg and dorsal foot, with the important exception of the first web space, which is the area of decreased sensation in this patient. This nerve also plays an important role in ankle eversion by providing motor innervation to the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis (i.e., the lateral compartment of the lower leg).

B) INCORRECT:

The tibial nerve, a mixed motor and sensory nerve, carries sensory input from the plantar surface of the foot and the area innervated by its branch, the sural nerve. It also innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg (e.g., gastrocnemius, soleus, plantaris, and the deep toe flexors). The tibial nerve does not provide sensory innervation to the first web space, the area of decreased sensation in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

The deep peroneal nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin between the first two toes. It also provides motor innervation to the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg (e.g., tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus), which dorsiflex the toes and ankle joint; thus, injury to the nerve can result in a high-stepping gait. Deep peroneal nerve compression can be caused by tight-fitting shoes, which are suggested by this patient's hallux valgus deformity (bunion). It may also occur following trauma, especially navicular fracture.

D) INCORRECT:

The sural nerve is a pure sensory nerve that supplies the skin over the posterolateral aspect of the distal third of the leg and the lateral border of the foot. The sural nerve does not provide sensation to the first web space, which is the area of decreased sensation in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The saphenous nerve is a pure sensory nerve that innervates the medial aspect of the calf and ankle. This nerve does not provide sensation to the first web space, which is the area of decreased sensation in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

The medial plantar nerve is a distal branch of the tibial nerve and provides sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the plantar foot, including the medial three and a half toes. It also provides motor innervation to the intrinsic toe flexors and abductor hallucis. The medial plantar nerve does not provide sensation to the first web space, which is the area of decreased sensation in this patient.
questions.hint: Weakness of toe dorsiflexion may also be seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with osteoarthritis of the knee comes to the physician for evaluation of weakness in his foot. Physical examination shows a swelling in the popliteal fossa. There is marked weakness when attempting to invert his right foot. He is unable to curl his toes. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show decreased sensation over which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The second dorsal web space, the anterolateral inferior third of the leg, and most of the foot dorsum (except for the first web space) receive sensory innervation from the superficial peroneal nerve. The motor portion of this nerve supplies the lateral compartment of the leg, allowing for foot eversion. Injury to the superficial peroneal nerve occurs secondary to entrapment at the lateral ankle or via fibular fracture, not as a result of the popliteal swelling seen in this patient. Likewise, deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with a superficial peroneal nerve injury.

B) CORRECT:

The sole of the foot, lateral foot, and posterolateral leg are innervated by sensory branches of the tibial nerve (nerve stem from L4–S3). The posterior compartment of the leg, responsible for foot inversion and plantarflexion of the toes and ankle, is innervated by motor branches of the tibial nerve. This patient's neurapraxia of the tibial nerve secondary to popliteal swelling would diminish the sensory and motor functions of these regions.

C) INCORRECT:

The sensory branch of the deep peroneal nerve provides sensation to the first web space, while the motor portion supplies the anterior compartment of the leg, which is responsible for foot and toe dorsiflexion. Injury is usually the result of anterior compartment compression or ski boot syndrome, not the popliteal swelling seen in this patient. Likewise, deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with deep peroneal nerve injury.

D) INCORRECT:

The medial plantar arch and the medial leg and foot are innervated by the saphenous nerve, which has a purely cutaneous sensory function. Therefore, this patient's motor deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with saphenous nerve injury. The saphenous nerve would also not be injured by popliteal swelling.

E) INCORRECT:

The lateral border of the foot is innervated by the sural nerve, which provides a purely cutaneous sensory function to the inferior portion of the posterolateral leg. Injury to the sural nerve is often secondary to calcaneal fracture or trauma, not popliteal swelling as this patient has. Likewise, deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with sural nerve injury.
questions.hint: Swelling of the popliteal fossa can lead to compression of the inlying structures, including the tibial nerve. Compression of the tibial nerve can result in neurapraxia, causing marked motor weakness of foot inversion and toe plantarflexion, as well as sensory deficits in the tibial nerve distribution.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, comes to the physician because of left ankle swelling for 2 months. She notes that the swelling is present throughout the day and decreases when she goes to sleep. One year ago, she had an episode of deep venous thrombosis after the delivery of her third child. Her prepregnancy BMI was 34 kg/m2. Examination shows distended, tortuous veins in the legs bilaterally and pitting edema of the left ankle. There are erythematous scaling patches on the medial side of the left ankle. Duplex ultrasonography is performed. Which of the following directions of blood flow would most likely confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Anterior tibial vein to popliteal vein
Popliteal vein to small saphenous vein
Femoral vein to external iliac vein
Great saphenous vein to femoral vein
Dorsal venous arch to great saphenous vein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Venous blood flowing from the anterior tibial vein to the popliteal vein indicates normal blood flow from a peripheral deep vein to a deep vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.

B) CORRECT:

Venous blood flowing from the deep popliteal vein to the superficial small saphenous vein indicates retrograde blood flow and confirms the diagnosis of chronic venous disease. Normally, the small saphenous vein would arise from the dorsal venous arch and drain into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction. In a patient with chronic venous disease, however, incompetence of the venous valves caused by elevated venous pressure (e.g., due to pregnancy, increased BMI, prior thrombosis) leads to blood reflux from deep into superficial veins. This results in the formation of varicose veins, and ultimately edema and skin changes (e.g., stasis dermatitis), as seen in this patient. First-line treatment consists of conservative measures such as leg elevation, compression therapy, and application of topical dermatologic agents.
Image Description:

The superficial veins are depicted in the right leg:
- Great saphenous vein: arises from the medial end of the dorsal venous arch, courses in front of the medial malleolus, up the medial aspect of the leg, behind the medial border of the patella, and up the medial aspect of the thigh. It terminates by draining into the femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction, which is typically located ~4 cm inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.
- Short saphenous vein: arises from the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch, courses behind the lateral malleolus, and up the posterior aspect of the leg. It terminates by draining into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction, which usually lies in the popliteal fossa (not shown here).

The deep veins are depicted in the left leg:
- Peripheral deep veins: anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and fibular (peroneal) veins
- Popliteal vein: formed by the confluence of the peripheral deep veins
- Femoral vein: continuation of the popliteal vein. It begins at the adductor hiatus and accompanies the femoral artery throughout its course. The deep femoral vein (profunda femoris) is the main tributary of the femoral vein.
- External iliac vein: continuation of the femoral vein. It begins behind the inguinal ligament and drains into the common iliac vein.

C) INCORRECT:

Venous blood flowing from the femoral vein to the external iliac vein indicates normal blood flow from a deep vein to a proximal deep vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.

D) INCORRECT:

Venous blood flowing from the great saphenous vein to the femoral vein indicates normal blood flow from a superficial to a deep vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.

E) INCORRECT:

The dorsal venous arch is a superficial vein that gives rise to the great saphenous vein and small saphenous vein, which are superficial veins that originate from the medial and lateral sides of the dorsal venous arch, respectively. Therefore, blood normally flows from the dorsal venous arch to the great saphenous vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.
questions.hint: Distended and tortuous veins in both legs, ankle edema, and skin changes on the medial ankle indicate chronic venous disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after falling down the stairs in her house. She began taking levofloxacin 4 days ago for community-acquired pneumonia and takes no other medications. Physical examination shows severe tenderness, swelling, erythema, and decreased range of motion of her left ankle joint. An MRI of her left ankle shows a partial tear in the anterior talofibular ligament and a complete tear in the tendon of the muscle that originates from the lower two-thirds of the fibula's lateral surface and inserts onto the base of the fifth metatarsal bone. The affected muscle normally aids in which of the following foot movements?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lateral rotation of the foot is mostly the result of lateral rotation of the hip joint, for which the gluteus maximus, iliopsoas, piriformis, and obturator externus muscles are responsible. None of these muscles are located in the lower leg, the location of this patient's ruptured tendon.

B) CORRECT:

The peroneus brevis muscle, located in the lateral compartment of the leg, is primarily responsible for eversion of the foot and assists in plantarflexion of the foot. Injury manifests primarily with impaired foot eversion while plantarflexion may be normal or weak. Rupture of the tendon is an uncommon severe complication of fluoroquinolones (e.g., levofloxacin), particularly in older patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Dorsiflexion of the foot is controlled by the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg (i.e., tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, and peroneus tertius). Although the peroneus tertius inserts on the base of the fifth metatarsal bone, as seen in the muscle injured in this patient, it originates from the distal third of the medial fibula, not the lower two-thirds of the lateral fibula. None of the other muscles of the anterior compartment originate from the lateral fibula or insert on the base of the fifth metatarsal bone. The tibialis anterior originates from the lateral tibial condyle and proximal two-thirds of the lateral tibia, and inserts on the medial cuneiform and base of the first metatarsal bone. The extensor digitorum longus originates in the same place as the tibialis anterior and divides into four tendons that insert into the bases of the middle and distal phalanges of the second to fifth toes. Finally, the extensor hallucis longus originates from the middle third of the medial fibula, and inserts into the dorsal base of the distal phalanx of the hallux.

D) INCORRECT:

Inversion of the foot is controlled by the tibialis posterior (primary) and the tibialis anterior (accessory) muscles. The tibialis posterior originates from the posterior upper fibula and tibia, and it inserts onto the navicular and intermediate cuneiform bones and the bases of the second to the fourth metatarsal bones. The tibialis anterior originates from the lateral tibial condyle and proximal two-thirds of the lateral tibia, and inserts onto the medial cuneiform bone and the base of the first metatarsal bone. Neither of these corresponds to the tendon injury described in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Medial rotation of the foot is primarily the result of medial rotation of the hip joint, for which the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fascia lata muscles are responsible. None of these muscles are located in the lower leg, the location of this patient's ruptured tendon.
questions.hint: This movement would be impaired if the superficial peroneal nerve was injured.
